lg.l: As birds, having risen in the groves [in] the outer area,
chirp; as the orb [= sun] that the world worships that opens
hoards/the inner part of the lotus flower [in] ponds
Waking up the sleep of the superior town or Kūṭal
Of Ceḻiyaṉ [with] a lifted sword, so that kings’ heads shiver,
As the intense voice of the morning Muracam drum
Which was lofty, having obtained [special] classification,
Sounded together with the pure-white conch
[In] the temple of the Lord with an eye that opens [on] the forehead,
The temple marketplace of him who lifted [the banner] of the kite,m
The temple of the white [one] who raised the plough strongly,
The [temple] enclosure of him with a banner of the rooster,
The resting place of virtuous people who shone [in] the domain of virtue,
And the palace of the king that shone [in] the domain of valour;
Kōvalaṉ having gone, praising, having worshipped [with] hands
mother Kāvunti who was seated according to the [right] principles,
Saying, “Oh you who performs penance! I have been full of low feelings,
I [now] being one of the nature of having left the [righteous] path,
Having endured a difficult part in an unknown country
So that [The lady with] a body [like] fragrant flowers reached
[A state] of trembling misery. Until I come [back], having informed
My state to the ministers of the king in the ancient city [of Maturai]
Is there any objection [in] this way, oh venerable one,
Since [Kaṇṇaki] with green-gold bracelets is one at the guard [of your] feet?”
Kavunti [now] speaks: ‘You who have endured a singular [kind] of misery
[Because of] the ending of [your past] penances, along with [your] lady-love,
People in the domain of duty/virtuousness having proclaimed,
‘Leave the domain of valour [= brute violence]; strong Karma
Will feed [its consequences]’, people who cut away at [these] bonds
Will not take [to heart this good] nature, even if the mouth
Beats [as] a drum, the tongue being the drumstick.
[And] when the evil, intense Karma takes shape,
Besides being for those who unite
With women with curly tresses, the singular life of
The sorrow of separation, the sorrow of uniting
And the sorrow of him without a form, that breaks,
Is not for strong people [= ascetics].
Those who take, in [this] world, saying, ‘woman and food
Are [the only] pleasures’, having endured a distress there
That cannot be grasped, that made suffering,
Because of love, its support being desire
They having become witnesses [to that suffering], if only today [when]
They reached [a state of] affliction, [with] confusion [on] the side,
Because [Karma] is ancient - [it] coming in order to be ancient,
By many who had passed on [already] -
The man who endured cruel misery, [his] lady-love having left [him],
[After] having gone along with [that] lady because of [his] father’s command
— the fact that he produced the first one of the Vedas (Brahma) —
Did you not know? Is it not a long[-remembered] saying?
Having lost his rule on earth because of gambling [with] dice,
He reached the hot forest with [his wife of] a tender nature.
He was not one who separated because of love.
The lady-love was not one of small-mindedness
The leaving, having put in the middle of the night
The one [with] choice jewels was strong Karma, was it not?
If one says, ‘it was a misjudgement [on the part of] the girl’,
You do not say [so] — You are not such a person.
Is it not so that you have obtained life without separation
When you reach the city of Kūṭal of the king,
Return here, having learnt [what is to be done].’
[Kāvunti] saying thus, [Kōvalaṉ] having gone through an underground passage
In which groups of elephants with big trunks are moved through the mighty moat
By the expanse of shining waters that lay in a curved shape,
With a thicket surrounded by a guard [of soldiers],
Having entered, [into] the entrance of a protected fort,
Going [in] unsuspected by the Yavaṉar [with] murderous swords,
[The fort] being as though having opened the lid
Of a box of rare jewels of him with a thousand eyes [= Indra],
On the street in which banners sway, the western wind having blown [in],
Women who have crossed the boundary [of decency],
Along with [their] loving, rich men driving boats with [many] storeys
Of a tall nature on a shore of a river-islet in which white sand had been deposited,
With blooming flowers, [upon] the front/main ghat in which myrobalan [creepers] were high
[Because of] the arriving floods of the Vaiyai,
[Those girls], embracing flower[-strewn] rafts, desiring a bath [in] the floods,
Inserting, so that they are in the hair, cool [and] fragrant jasmine,
waterlily from which water [still] spills down and blue waterlilies
Whose eyes [=petals] open; putting on along with pearls [from] the big, pretty ghat
Of Koṟkai, a garland in which the pollen of cool, red waterlilies expands,
[Waterlilies] that have been linked to blossoms of white jasmine-flowers,
Playing with rich sandal paste from the southern Malaya region,
Desiring a celebration/sport [in] the groves of the ancient town [with] golden banners,
As [girls with] hanging adornments praised [their] husbands on the front-yards
[Bathed in] the young moon’s light, in the afternoon,
Being seated sweetly upon a bed upon which flowers were strewn,
Having worn ointments [and] a flower-silk cloth upon the waist,
Having united Kuṭacam flowers to the tresses [already adorned with]
Kuriñci blossoms [from the same] day, along with red Kūtāḷam flower
From the slopes of little mountains, having applied vermillion colour on the breasts,
Having put on a flourishing flower-garland [with] curved [petals with] nectar
Upon the body to which vermillion powder was joined,
Along with a pretty string of corals;
as exuberant Kūṭal manifests red decorations
For the king [with] the Vacciram weapon that cut off the wings of the mountain,
The king [that is the] rainy season will arrive with the northern winds.
In the storeyed houses that touched the sky, of the excellence of learned men,
Innocent women with firewood that gave [the fragrance of] eaglewood
Having sat at the wide fires, in the cold season in which the narrow embrasures
Are shut, along with [their] male lovers with chests [with] fragrant, sandal paste,
And the cold season in which white clouds seldom appear,
The ob [with] expanding rays [= the sun] having risen in the south,
As women [from] wealthy houses and [their] husbands, desiring [so],
Experience the young [= gentle] sunlight on the frontyards [with] young moonlight,
Apart from that over there, at the time of passing thoughts in which affliction ends,
Ladies with creepers for bodies, along with [their] great husbands, asking,
‘Where is he, the king of the cold [season] of the union [to the month of] Paṅkuṉi
That witnesses the festival of tall, fiery-eyed Kāma’s bow [in] Kūṭal
Of the royal prince, fast ships from the vast, wide expanse [= the ocean]
Carrying eaglewood, fine cloth, sandal, fragrances and hoards of black camphor
[By] the Toṇṭiyōr into [those] fleets having entered [it], along with the east wind that it arrived with?’
‘Where is he, the pleasant, young summer, that embraces [his] joyful companion
[In] the king’s Kūṭal, [the summer] having entered with the southern breeze
[From] the Potiyil mountain, as the rich creeper of Mātavi [for] garlands grows,
As the groves and forests offer fragrant blossoms?’
As herds of bull elephants tremble along with the female herd that desire calves,
As fires [in] forests are born In the good land that has the hill [of Potiyil] in which the sun stood,
As the summer king that ruled Kūṭal, having subdued intense flames,
Entering with the western wind, [now] setting out [to] a different region,
On the last day of intense heat that sweltered (?),
As the royal prince gave delight [to] committed companions
In pleasure gardens that are granted by the beautiful time [of year],
yak-tail fans, chowries, bags to store gold and swords [with] sharp tips,
Women [with] gold bracelets [with] a life that does not change
[With respect to] the prosperity that was obtained
Having united [in] a new union, [being] those who drank pretty, sweet toddy
That was offered by servant-girls in cups of red-gold getting drunk,
Apart from the way in which spotted [and] striped groups of bees were embracing,
[The girls] having scared away [the bees to] places that were empty [of bees]
In the evening [with] fragrant flowers, as young pearls [= teeth] bud
[On] red mouths [like] petals [of] the Ilavu flower, they with lily[-like] eyes
That spoke without praise during the time of sulking [with their lovers]
Will not united with [their] tongues to the phrases [through] eight [ways].
[Then], as though having made open buds of pretty, red waterlilies [= having smiled]
[With] words of laughter, the rich ends of brows [like] murderous bows rolling/furrowing
And a battle of the flourishing ends of eyes long [like] red carps,
And the streets of the guardian of the world which give joy [with girls]
Who sweat, where the small foreheads [with] a Tilakam mark bud,
Who observe along with [their] rich men the opportune moment,
And the ladies [with] the Talaikkōl staff of an excellence which is difficult to confuse,
That expounds that which is reached through the field of Abhinaya of four types of tradition,
And the landscapes (?) of seven types, [with] lives [in] protected houses,
Staying in line [with] the crowned king, [the ladies being]
Of a superiority from which reproach leaves, in which they do not carry burnt tiles,
Having learnt the measures of two constituents, namely the royal nature and the public nature,
Having fully understood the orchestral instruments that join [with]
Dancing of an unconfused tradition, the Vari dance, the Pāṇi songs and Tūkku music (?),
The girls that are [from] ancient [traditions] that sing Vāram songs,
The dancing girl of the main song and the dancing girl of the secondary song
Not deviating in daily manners [= duties] that do not obstruct [with respect to]
Balancing the eight [notes till] the end, belonging to the usages befitting of joy
Of four distinct types, [with] 1008 Kaḻañcus [of gold as a reward],
And, big streets of those of the sixty-four arts [with] sweet words
That ridicule melody and [its] secondary [topics], that stay in [a state of] pleasant sleep
[Even in] the delightful daytime, whether they be performers of tapas,
Even [their] knowledge that is difficult to obtain becoming another matter,
As though having been caught in a net of glances by those ladies like attacking spirits,
Whether they are young men who look for an enjoyable time
Like bees [to their] befitting flowers, or whether they are innocent ladies with passionate guests,
And the market-street with wealth that the king desires, in which prosperity whose varieties
Are not discernible are mixed up, [containing] carts, two-wheeled carts, chariots (?) [with] sapphires,
Armour into which the body enters, [elephant-] goads [with] desirous sapphires,
Protection to wear [on] the skin, cures that stop itching/festering,
Round/globular balls (bludgeons? Perfumed bludgeons?), pure white chowries,
Boar[-shaped] shields/garments, framed (?) shields/garments, forest shields/garments,
Pikes to pierce the hard things, items made out of copper, items made [with] bell metal,
Items made newly, items to adorn garlands, items to strengthen saws/swords(?),
Items made to mash [even] ivory/conch, items [that make] smoke, fragrant pastes,
And the shining items to adorn/string flowers;
as the fine, subtle Kōṭi quality of diamonds
Beautiful and lustrous, in four manners, [the diamonds] that were declared
By those of the treatise who were undiminished in [their] nature,
[The faults called] crow’s feet, blot/stain, dot/point and streaks having left [the gem],
And the shining items - the green rays of a completely green bodied [emerald] that had abandoned
[The faults that were] streaks and faults, along with darkness,
And the types [of ruby] that shone, not failing in the kinds of injunctions,
[Being the four types, namely] Patumam, Nīlam, Vintam and Paṭitam,
Those that were such, being clear in gold [colour] like the form of Puṣya Nakṣatra,
And those of a form of clear toddy, bright [with] faultless rays
Those that are such, having clarified darkness/dullness,
Those with two different forms, and the sapphires that release shining rays,
In different [kinds of] beauty [through] a single appearance/[of] a single quality
And those that are clear, [being] stain-free of faults that are made to appear
From wind, earth, stone or water, and the circular section [of gems, i.e. pearls/corals]
Of that natures that came like the moon, Jupiter and Mars,
Those with inner holes, those with bends inside the gem,
And the red/perfect creeper-flags from which twists [= faults] had left,
Having been lofty, receiving [the right to be] collected [by] people who know the types [of gems?]
[i.e., advertising the sale of precious goods to knowledgeable people],
The street of yield that does not know the wrath of enmity,
People who understand gold of superior principles that are
Cātarūpam, Kiḷicciṟai, Āṭakam [and] Cāmpūnatam, having eliminated agitating sorrow,
And the street that shines [with] beauty in which shining banners are lifted,
And the streets of cloth/garments that were dense [with] fragrant cloth,
In several hundred heaps in which the different types were not clear,
Of [cloth made of] thread, of fur and of fine silk-threads,
As those with a full [= heavy?] wooden-stick balance, those with barrels for the Paṟai drum,
And those that measure [with] a wooden scale (?) wander about everywhere,
And the grain-streets in which grains were heaped along with sacks of black pepper
Regardless of the season, and the market/bazaar-street [with] the evening [place] (?), and the squares,
And the four different streets whose distinction was clear,
[Thus], Kōvalaṉ having roamed [in such] common areas, forked roads and streets,
Having seen the great town of the Guardian [= Pāṇṭiya king] [under] the shade
Of an arbour [with] a banner [like] a green/fresh creeper, into which the hot rays
That had roamed in the belly of the skies does not enter, reaching [a state of] joy,
He went to the outside of the bannered fortress.
